// BREZU
// Slide 1
Longer Duration of Action vs. Salbunation
Subjects with the protection of EIA after medication using FEV1 as Parameter \n (n = 26)
Inhaled Procaterol Oral Procaterol Inhaled Salbutamol
P value\n 5.0 hr = 0.0000001*\n 9.5 hr = 0.00000043*\n
Both inhaled and oral procaterol provide a similar degree and duration of protection against EIA (9.5hrs)
Chu, J, Tuazon OA et al. A comparison of the protective efficacy of procaterol aerosol and syrup in exercise-induced asthma. Am J Resp and Critical Care Med 2000; 161 (3) A345
// Slide 2
Prevents Nocturnal Asthma
\"…that procaterol significantly inhibited the reduction in pulmonary flow rates early in the morning hours, as well as significantly decreasing the amount of wheezing measured at the time.\"
// Slide 3
Faster Onset of Action vs. Salbutamol Comparative study on Bronchadilating Effects of Procaterol and Salbutamol Salbutamol Procaterol Salbutamol (n = 25)\nProcaterol (n = 25)
// Slide 4
No Drug Tolerance
The effectiveness of Procaterol was maintained through 3 months of treatment unlike Salbutamol, which appeared to decrease.
AFTER 1 MONTH AFTER 3 MONTHS
Comparison of mean percent of FEV1 from predose values during 8hr. postdose between: \n Group I: received procaterol 0.05 mg twice daily for 2wk followed by 0.10mg twice daily for 10wk. \n Group II: received Salbutamol 2mg three times a day for 2wk followed by 4mg three times aday for 10wk.
// CLARITHROMYCIN
// Slide 1
CLARITHROMYCIN Clarithro - Natrapharm
250mg / 5mL suspension\n 125mg / 5mL suspension
// Slide 2
Indications • LOWER RESPIRATORY TRACT INFECTION (E.G. BRONCHITIS, PNEUMONIA) \n• UPPER RESPIRATORY TRACT INFECTION (E.G. STREPTOCOCCAL PHARYNGITIS) \n• SKIN AND SKIN STRUCTURE INFECTIONS (E.G. IMPETIGO, FOLLICULITIS, CELLULITIS) \n• DISSEMINATED OR LOCALIZED MYCOBACTERIAL INFECTIONS DUE TO MYCOBACTERIUM OR MYCOBACTERIUM INTRA CELLULARE \n• LOCALIZED INFECTIONS DUE TO MYCOBACTERIUM CHELONAE, MYCOBACTERIUM FORTUITUIM, OR MYCOBACTERIUM KANSAII
// Slide 3
Dosage in Patients with Renal Impairment
In children with creatinine clearance with less than 30mL min., the dosage of CLARITHROMYCIN should be reduced by one-half. 250mg once daily or 250mg twice on more severe infections. Dosage should not be continued beyond 14 days in these patients.
// Slide 4
Dosage in Patients with Mycobacterial Infection
In children with sisseminated or localized mycobacterial infection (M. Avium, M. Intracellulare, M. Chelonae, M. Fortiumtum, M. Kansasii), the recommended dose is 15 to 30 mg/kg CLARITHROMTHYCON per day divided in to 2 doses.
// Slide 5
The combination of a beta-lactam plus a macrolide could be suggested in the first-line treatment of CAp in the immunocompetent children aged 2 to 5 years old.
Esposito et al. Characteristics of Streptococcus pneumonia and Atypical Bacterial Infection in Children 2 to 5 years of age with Community-Acquired Pneumonia.\n Clinical Diseases 2002; \n 35:1345-52
// Slide 6
Primary combination treatment with MACROLIDES in the areas where there is a high prevalence of atypical organism.
Chetty K. Thomson AH. Management of Community-Acquired Pneumonia in Children.\n Paediatr Drugs.\n 2007:9(6)-401-11
// Slide 7
Children < 8kg or < 18lbs. should be dosed on a per kg or per lb. basis (approx. 7,5 mg/kg BID or 3.4 mg/lb BIF)
// Heraclene
// Slide 1
Dibencozide Heraclene For Picky and Fussy Eaters Children with little or no appetite The only protein building, non-sedating appetite stimulant
// Slide 2
Protein Building Process
Acts as the key coenzyme in the activation of incorporation of amino to form protein molecules
Contributes to accelerated formation and repair of bady tissues
Facilitates optimum utilization of dietary protein intake
// Slide 3
Appetite Stimulant
As amino acid incorporation is accelerated, more polypeptide chains are formed in to bigger protein molecules, thus, the artificial lack of amino acid in the amino acid pool. This results to stimulation of appetite.
\"There is a marked effect upon appetite\" after 7 to 31 days of treatment with Heraclene.
// Slide 4
Non-Sedating\n Will not cause drowsiness
Excellent Tolerance\n No side effects\n No contraindications
Convenient Capsule Form\n Tasteless and Odorless\n Child will hardly notice medicine
// Slide 5
Prescription Information
Formulation\n Each Capsule contains Dibencozide - 1mg
Actions
Dibencozide increases the protein \"efficiency coefficient\" (i.e. the percentage of bound nutrition for protein build up in the body compared to ingested nitrogen with food intake). The initial sign of effectiveness is manisfested by a marked increase in appetite.
Thus, DIBENCOZIDE 1. Facilitates optimum utilization of dietary intake\n 2. Contributes to the formation and repair of body tissue\n 3. Stimulates appetite
// Slide 6
Indications
• Poor appetite\n • Adjuvant to treatment of luberculous and other chronic ailments\n • Convalescense from acute infection or surgery\n • Faulty nutrition in older people\n • Premature babies, Low birth weight. Retardted growth
Dosage
Premature babies / infants: 1 Capsule daily (Capsule may be opened. Odorless and tasteless powder can be mixed in to milk or juice.) Children and Adolescents: 2-3 Capsules daily (3 capsules daily or as prescribed by Physician) Adults: 2-3 Capsules daily (3 capsules daily or as prescribed by Physician)
// Slide 7
Cautions
Food, Drugs, Devices and Cosmetics Act prohibits dispensing without prescription.
Presentation Box of 100 capsules Reference
1. F. Gillot and J.L. Condudal. Clinical Trial of a Non-Steroidical an Anaboloc drugs in Pediatrics L. Quest Medical 25 May 1968 11-899-902 \n 2. P. Debray, Cobamide-Coenzyme in Pediatric Practice: Medicine Infantile, 1966.
// HERACLENE 1mg
// Slide 1
For the most delicate of patients… 1mg Capsule Promotes Weight, Promotes Health
The only protein-building appetite stimulant for low birth weight and premature babies.
// Slide 2
The only protein-building appetite stimulant Proven effective, proven safe for low birth weight babies
• Prospective, double-blind, randomized, controlled trial to evaluate efficacy add safety of Dibencozide in low birth weight infants < 35 weeks age of gestation\n • Primary objective: to determine difference in mean weight gain between infants given preterm milk formula with placebo
Result:
• Dibencozide group had statistically significant 4g/day difference in mean weight gain compared to placebo\n • Dibencozide group had shorter duration of intervention compared to placebo (13.2 days + vs. 15.7 days + 9.9)\n • Risk Ratio and NNT for sepsis, pneumonia, necrotizing enterocolitis and death: benefit towards dibencozide
// Slide 3
Protein Builder The Protein Building Process
• acts as the key coenzyme in the activation of incorporation of amino acids to form protein molecules\n • contributes to accelerated formation and repair of body tissues\n • facilitates optimum utilization of dietary protein intake
// Slide 4
Formulation
Each Capsule contains Dibencozide 1mg
Actions
Each DIBENCOZIDE increases the protein \"efficiency coefficient\", i.e., the percentage of \"bound nitrogen\" for protein build up in the body compared to \"ingested nitrogen with food intake\". The initial sign of effectiveness is manifested by marked increase in appetite.
Thus, DIBENCOZIDE 1. Facilitates optimum utilization of dietary intake\n 2. Contributes to the formation and repair of body tissue\n 3. Stimulates appetite
Indications
1. Poor appetite in children and adults\n 2. Adjuvant to treatment of tuberculosis and other chronic ailments\n 3. Convalescence from acute infection of surgery\n 4.Faulty nutrition in older people
Dosage
Children and adolescents: 1 capsule daily or as prescribed by the physician.\n Adults: 3 capsules daily or as prescribed by the physician.\n The initial sign of its effectiveness is manifested by a marked increase in appetite.
Caution
Food, Drugs, Devices and Cosmetics Act prohibits dispensing without prescription.
Presentation Box of 50 capsules
// KIDZ KIT
// Slide 1 suspension
Pyrazinamide Z®cure 500mg/5ml
// For Slide 1 and 2
Rifampicin Natricin® Forte 200mg/5ml
Isoniazid+ Pyridoxine HCI Curazid® Forte 200mg/10ml per 5ml syrup
// MONTEMAX
// Slide 1
4mg, 5mg, and 10mg chewable tablet
Achieve control (in Asthma and Allergic Rhinitis)
Should be taken once daily.
For Asthma, the dose should be taken in the evening to prevent nocturnal attack.
For Allergic Rhinitis, the time of administration may be individualized to suit patient needs.
Patients with both Asthma and Allergic Rhinitis, should only take one tablet daily in the evening.
Patients below 15 years old with Asthma and or Allergic Rhinitis: one 5 mg chewable tablet daily, no adjustment within the age group is necessary.
Children between 2 to 5 years old with Asthma and/or Allergic Rhinitis: one 4mg chewable tablet daily.
// Slide 2
Recommended Asthma Medications
Severity Daily Controller Medication Other Options
Mild Persistent Moderate Persistent Severe Persistent
• Inhaled glucocorticosteroid (100 - 400 μg budesonide or equivalent)
• Inhaled glucocorticosteroid (400 - 800 μg budesonide or equivalent)
• Inhaled glucocorticosteroid (> 800 μg budesonide or equivalent) plus one or more of the following, if needed:\n a. Sustained-release theophylline\n b. Cromone\n c. Leukotriene modifier - MONTELUKAST
• Sustained-release theophylline\n • Cromone\n • Leukotriene modifier - MONTELUKAST
• Inhaled glucocorticosteroid (< 800g budesonide or equivalent) along with any of the following:\n a. sustained-release theophylline\n b. plus long-acting inhaled β2- agonist\n c. Leukotriene modifier - MONTELUKAST
// Slide 3
Classification of Allergic Rhinitis: ARIA Guidelines
Intermittent Persistent Mild Moderate - Severe
> 4 days a week or < 4 weeks
• normal sleep\n • no impairment of daily activities, sport, or leisure\n • normal work and school\n • no troublesome symptoms\n
• abnormal sleep\n • impairment of daily activities, sport, or leisure\n • abnormal work and school\n • troublesome symptoms\n
// Slide 4
Management of Allergic Rhinitis: ARIA Guidelines
// NATRAVOX
// Slide 1
Co-amoxiclave
156mg/5mL | 228/5mL \n 312mg/5mL | 457mg/5mL/suspension
\"The prudent step-up against key pathogens.\"
// Slide 2
For Optimal Antimicrobial Treatment in Respiratory Tract Infections
Aim for Bacteria Eradication Minimize Resistance Emergence Choose…
// Slide 3
In the treatment of Respiratory Tract Infections
CLINICAL CURE + BACTERIAL ERADICATION
=
Prevention of RELAPSE and ANTIBIOTIC RESISTANCE
// Slide 4
\"When evaluating the efficacy of antibiotics for treatment of RTI, assessment of clinical cure may not be the most relevant parameter, as if it may not related to microbiological medication… of infecting pathogens.\"
// Slide 5
\"…failure to eradicate bacteria may promote the emergence and dissemination of antimicrobial-resistant clones. Pharmakinetic or Pharmadynamic parameters can be used to predict the bacteriological efficay of antimicrobial therapy. In conclusion, the aim of antimicrobial therapy in respiratory infection should be the eradication of the infecting organisms.\"
// Slide 6
The Three Most Common Pathogens of the Respiratory Tract Infections are:
Streotoccocus Pneumoniae Gram (+) Haemophilus Influenzae Gram (+) Moraxella Catarrhalis Gram (+)
// Slide 7
\"…Streotoccocus Pneumoniae, Haemophilus influenzae and Moraxella Catarrhalis are the most common community-acquired respiratory bacterial pathogens, and an increase in their resistance to the orally administered antimicrobial agents used to treat these infections has emerged as a world-wide problem.\"
// Slide 8 Indications Genito Urinary Tract and Abdominal Infections
Examples include cystitis (especially when recurrent or not complicated, but not prostatitis) septic abortion, pelvic or puerperal sepsis and intra-abdominal sepsis. These infections are often caused by Enterobacteriaceae (mainly Escherichia coli), Staphyloccocus saprophyticus, and Enteroccocus species.
Skin and Soft Tissues Infections
Examples include cellulitis, animal bites, and severe dental abcess with spreading cellulitis caused by Staphyloccocus aureus, Streptoccocus pyogenes, and Bacteriodes species.
// Slide 9
Convenient step-up against key Pathogens.
Well tolerated and safe for children.
No DIDP (Diisodecyl Phthalate) content.
